entry.title: Derivation of Einstein's Fields Equation
entry.content:
We are going to cover two ways of the derivation of Einstein’s equation, one is based on physical analysis, anther one utilizing the variational approaches.

Energy-Momentum Tensor

Def(Energy-Momentum Tensor):

Given the action $I$, the energy momentum tensor of a physical system is defined as

$$T_{\mu u}:=-\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{-g}}\dfrac{\delta I}{\delta g^{\mu u}},$$

where $\displaystyle\dfrac{\delta I}{\delta g^{\mu u}}$ is variational derivatives and $g$ represents the determinant of matrix $(g_{\mu u})$.

Example:

In electrodynamics, the action is (there may be some typos about the coefficients, but that does not matter at all)
$$
egin{equation}\label{1.1.1}I_{em}=-\dfrac{1}{4}\int d^{4}x\sqrt{-g}F^{\mu u}F_{\mu u}.\end{equation}
$$

If we introduce $ ext{magnetic vector protential }A_{\mu}$ (It is a valuable to check that this definition automatically satisfies the 4-dimensional Maxell’s equation $\partial_{[\alpha}F_{\mu u]}=0$. Additionally, you can re-express the Maxell’s equation in a more symmetric form by $ ext{Hodge star }*:\Lambda^{k}(V) ightarrow\Lambda^{n-k}(V)$ in differential manifolds. Here I just skip it because it thouroughly digresses from the topic :) )

$$F_{\mu u}\equiv\partial_{\mu}A_{ u}-\partial_{ u}A_{\mu}.$$

Then one can show that the energy momentum defined here is compatible with that we already knew in electrodynamics classes:

Claim(Energy-Momentum Tensor of Electrodynamics):

$$
egin{equation}\label{1.1.2}T_{ ho\sigma}^{em}=-\dfrac{2}{\sqrt{-g}}\dfrac{\delta I_{em}}{\delta g^{ ho\sigma}}=-\dfrac{1}{4}g_{ ho\sigma}F^{2}+F_{ ho u}F_{\sigma}^{~ u}.\end{equation}
$$

##Proof:

(skipped)

Derivation Based on Functional Derivatives

Undoubtedly it is based on talent analyses on physics that Einstein firstly write down the Field Equation. The reason why I give you another approach at first is because of some pedagogical consideration.

Axiom:(Hilbert Action)

The action of general relativity is given by Hilbert that

$$I_{G}=\dfrac{1}{16\pi G}\int dx^{4}\sqrt{-g}R,$$

where $R$ is Ricci scalar.

Proposition(Einstein’s Field Equation):

$$
egin{equation}\label{1.2.1}R_{\mu u}-\dfrac{1}{2}g_{\mu u}R=8\pi GT_{\mu u}\end{equation}
$$

Proof:

$$\delta I_{G}=\dfrac{1}{16\pi G}\int dx^{4} igg[(\delta\sqrt{-g})g^{\mu u}R_{\mu u}+\sqrt{-g}(\delta g^{\mu u})R_{\mu u}+\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}\delta R_{\mu u} igg].$$

There is no harm to consider the derivation in the local inertial coordinate(think why?), that is, $g_{\mu u} ightarrow\eta_{\mu u}$ and $\varGamma_{\mu u}^{\sigma}=0$. Thus,
$$\delta R_{\mu k}=\partial_{k}\delta\varGamma_{\mu\lambda}^{\lambda}-\partial_{\lambda}\delta\varGamma_{\mu k}^{\lambda}+0+0-0-0.$$

And it is easy to check that $\delta\varGamma$ is always a tensor.(verify!) (Hint: Consider two distinct connections defined on the manifold and their affine connection’s behaviors under the coordinate tansformation.)

In this way,
$$
egin{align}\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}R_{\mu u}&=\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}(\partial_{ u}\delta\varGamma_{\mu\lambda}^{\lambda})-\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}(\partial_{\lambda}\delta\varGamma_{\mu u}^{\lambda}) onumber\=&\partial_{ u}(\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}\delta\varGamma_{\mu\lambda}^{\lambda})-\partial_{\lambda}(\sqrt{-g}g^{\mu u}\delta\varGamma_{\mu u}^{\lambda}),\end{align}
$$
which vanishes at the boundary of spacetime by integrating by parts.

So
$$
egin{align}\delta I_{G}&=\dfrac{1}{16\pi G}\int dx^{4} igg[(\delta\sqrt{-g})g^{\mu u}R_{\mu u}+\sqrt{-g}(\delta g^{\mu u})R_{\mu u} igg] onumber\&=\dfrac{1}{16\pi G}\int dx^{4}\left[\dfrac{\sqrt{-g}}{2}g^{ ho\sigma}g^{\mu u}R_{\mu u}\delta g_{ ho\sigma}+\sqrt{-g}(-g^{\mu ho}g^{ u\sigma}\delta g_{ ho\sigma})R_{\mu u} ight] onumber\&=\dfrac{1}{16\pi G}\int dx^{4}\sqrt{-g}\delta g_{ ho\sigma}\left(\dfrac{1}{2}g^{ ho\sigma}R-R^{ ho\sigma} ight), onumber\end{align}
$$
or (there are some nontivial indice contraction tricks in the above computation that I believe you can handle, so I just left them as exercises.)

$$\displaystyle\dfrac{\delta I_{G}}{\delta g^{ ho\sigma}}=\dfrac{\sqrt{-g}}{16\pi G}\left(-\dfrac{1}{2}g^{ ho\sigma}R-R^{ ho\sigma} ight).$$

On the other aspect, $\displaystyle\dfrac{\delta I_{G}}{\delta g^{ ho\sigma}}=-\dfrac{\sqrt{-g}}{2}T^{ ho\sigma}$.

At last, by reducing the indices we get $ ext{Einstein’s Field Equation}$:

$$
egin{equation}
R_{\mu u}-\dfrac{1}{2}g_{\mu u}R=8\pi GT_{\mu u}.
\end{equation}
$$

entry.title: Noether Theorem for Non-autonomous System
entry.content:
鉴于大多数物理书混淆概念，把 $ ext{Noether}$ 定理讲得天花乱坠还无比繁杂，这里给出真正正确清晰的定理表述，以正视听。

自治系统是下面非自治系统的一般情况，或参见[1].

以下约定记号: 下标为一的是非自治系统物理量, 无下标为自治系统的. 自治系统 $ ext{Lagrangian}$ 含时, 将时间并入广义坐标, 引入参数 $ au$, 使得真实运动 $x^{\mu}=\varphi( au)$ (约定 $x^{0}\equiv t$, $\mu=1,2,3$. 位形流形 $M_{1}=M imes\mathbb{R}$.

定义 1：位形流形 $M_1$ 上的拉氏量 $\mathcal{L}_1:TM ightarrow\mathbb{R}$ 定义为
$$\mathcal{L}_1\left(t, m{q},\dfrac{\partial t}{\partial au},\dfrac{\partial m{q}}{\partial au} ight):=\mathcal{L}\left(t,\dfrac{\partial m{q}/\partial au}{\partial t/\partial au}, m{q} ight)\dfrac{ m{d}t}{ m{d} au}.$$

定义 2：称光滑映射 $h$ 为容许映射, 若满足推前映射下拉式量不变, 即 $$\displaystyle orall m{v}\in TM_{1}, \mathcal{L}_1(h_{*} m{v})=\mathcal{L}_1( m{v})$$.

定理 1（Noether）：若系统 $(M_1,\mathcal{L}_1)$ 容许单参微分同胚映射 $h^{s}:M_1 ightarrow M_1$, 则存在首次积分
$$ egin{equation}\displaystyle I_{1}=\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d} x^{\mu}}{\mathrm{d} au} ight)}\cdot\dfrac{\partial h^{s}(x^{\mu})}{\partial s}.\end{equation}$$

证明：如前, 记 $x^{\mu}=\varphi( au)$ 为真实运动, 满足 E-L 方程. 依容许映射定义, 容许映射保持拉氏量不变, 故 $h^{s}x^{\mu}=:\Phi( au,s)$ 也满足 E-L 方程. 拉式量不变意为
$$0\equiv\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial s}=\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial x^{\mu}}\cdot\dfrac{\partial\Phi}{\partial s}+\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}x^{\mu}}{\mathrm{d} au} ight)}\cdot\dfrac{\partial}{\partial s}\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\Phi}{\mathrm{d} au} ight).$$
改 $ au$ 为参数后, E-L 方程成为
$$\dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d} au}\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}x^{\mu}}{\mathrm{d} au} ight)}=\dfrac{\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial x^{\mu}}.$$

推论 1：首次积分可以明显写为
$$ egin{equation}\displaystyle I_{1}=-\mathcal{H}\dfrac{h^{s}(t)}{\partial s}+\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\dot{ m{q}}}\cdot\dfrac{h^{s}( m{q})}{\partial s}.\end{equation}$$

证明：对前半项的 $x^{0}$ 分量, 有
$$ egin{align}
\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}_{1}}{\partial\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d} x^{0}}{\mathrm{ d} au} ight)} &= \dfrac{\partial}{\partial\left(\dfrac{\mathrm{d}x^0}{\mathrm{d} au} ight)}\left(\mathcal{L}\left(t,\dfrac{\mathrm{d} m{q}/\mathrm{d} au}{\mathrm{d}t/\mathrm{d} au} ight)\dfrac{\mathrm{d}t}{\mathrm{d} au} ight) onumber\
&=\mathcal{L}+\left[\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\dot{ m{q}}}\cdot\left(-\dfrac{\mathrm{d} m{q}/\mathrm{d} au}{(\mathrm{d}t/\mathrm{d} au)^{2}} ight) ight]\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}t}{\mathrm{d} au} onumber\
&=\mathcal{L}-\dot{ m{q}}\dfrac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\dot{ m{q}}}=\mathcal{H}. onumber
\end{align}$$
其余同理, 留作练习.

参考文献：

[1] Anold, 经典力学中的数学方法. 高教社.
